On Tue, 25 May 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> I don't like the built-in assumption that tests belong to production
> code. A test is just another client of the production code....

While the test code is generally not run in production systems, I think
of the unit tests as an essential, integral part of any chunk of code.
Leaving out unit tests would be like--well, leaving out large chunks of
the code itself. Code without tests is only half-written code.

So in that sense, to me, if you're going to be using files for storage
of code units anyway, putting the tests in a separate file seems akin to
just chopping the class randomly in half, and putting half in one file,
and half in the other. After all, from a TDD programmer's point of view,
the tests and code are an inseparable chunk.

> ...and clients do not belong to providers. The implied dependency is
> in the wrong direction and generally that way lie dragons.

In fact, as I've been doing more and more acceptance testing, I am
seeing more and more cases where the code is merely a subservient
dependency on the test. The tests are, after all, where we specified
just what the code is to do, and where most of hard work (design and
specification) was done. If you remove all the code, it can relatively
easily be recreated, so long as you have those tests. If you delete the
tests, you now have a pile of code with no specification of what it
should do, only some behaviour that you can't safely modify. Losing the
tests and keeping the code is akin in this case to losing your source
code and being left only with compiled binaries.

> > I don't see what the problem with [including tests in production
> > code] is. It might cause a bit of code bloat, but that's often not a
> > problem in many projects.
>
> I disagree with the notion that code bloat is not a common problem.
> Refactoring exists in part because of code bloat.

Actually, "code bloat" was possibly the wrong term to use here. I
was refering to things like your distribution files getting larger.
For example, the JAR files I roll out into production often include
compiled versions of all of the unit tests, even though that code is not
necessary in production. That may make my JAR file twice the size it
would be otherwise, but in most circumstances I don't really care enough
to do the work to try to remove the test code.

> >  > This brings up something I am struggling with: in C#/NUnit, we can
> >  > declare a test without extending TestCase (even if we frequently extend
> >  > Assert, anyway). Is there some great benefit to this over the way we do
> >  > it in JUnit, SUnit, RubyUnit, PyUnit, ...?
>...
> I know it's possible, but I don't know why it's valuable. Can someone
> with experience doing both make a comparison? Weblog? Anything?

I think it's valuable because it gives you a lot more leway to play with
the design of your testing framework within a particular application. I
know that I often feel that certain refactoring directions I'd like to
try are closed to me because of the fairly strict structure of the JUnit
testing framework.

A "pain" that I've been feeling over the last few years has been the
tension between code that is in an external library, and code that is
in "my" source repository. For some things, the pain is bad enough, and
my need for flexability strong enough, that I just import the source
code for the external package and effectively start maintaining it
myself. This introduces a maintenance load, however, if I'm also going
to track the changes from the external package. I think that being
given more flexability in how one interfaces with an external chunk of
code lessens this tension. That's one thing that has, over the past few
years, started driving me away from the very static and declarative Java
model ("this interaface is declared as such, and may only be used in
this way") more towards the Smalltalk model, where an interface can be
thought of as any group of messages that one object sends to another.

I'm sure that this message is not terribly clear; my thoughts on this
topic are actually not terribly well formed at this time. But perhaps it
gives you an inkling of what I'm grasping towards here.
